abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Real Property
            Registration and Cadastre Project for Croatia were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the challenges
            of developing an information technology (IT) system,
            particularly one involving two agencies, should be taken
            into account during project design and when assessing
            project risks. While the Project Appraisal Document (PAD)
            envisaged a relatively simple IT system for sharing
            information, the implementing agencies opted for a
            comprehensive, and more complex, joint information system.
            It took some time for the implementing agencies to fully
            understand and agree on this activity, with the resultant
            lost time. This has been the pattern throughout the region
            with land administration IT systems, so Croatia was not
            alone is falling behind schedule. The development of
            software also suffered from other common problems the
            successful bidder's failure to recognize the complexity
            of the task and the contractor's fielding of
            under-qualified staff. This resulted in delays and the
            requests for extension. The complexity of such IT systems is
            both a key to success and institutional reforms, but also
            demanding in terms of implementation, management, resource
            allocation and procurement support. This is the case in
            many, if not all, land administration projects. Some
            important lessons in terms of project design, realistic
            implementation schedules, and costs against
            benefits/development outcome deserve to be highlighted. The
            project successfully achieved major institutional reform
            through a process oriented investment project. However the
            time and costs were significant, including a 21 month
            extension to complete the IT system, a key part of the
            reform. Such process oriented investment projects can
            implement real institutional and system-wide reform if the
            counterparts are willing, but takes time, often longer than
            the typical Bank project timeframe. However, if Bank
            management and the client are willing, the payoff is
            substantial and highly sustainable.
